document.masterDocTitle: Discovery of a New Species of Gnypeta Thomson, 1858 (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Aleocharinae) in Korea

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. Habitat of
Gnypeta koreana
. Korea: Gangwon Prov., Gangreung-si, Okgye-myeon, Jusu-ri, Bondeung-bridge.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Gnypeta koreana
Song and Ahn, new species
( Figs. 2–16 ) Zoobank.org/
urn:lsid:zoobank.org:act: 94ABFE49-8A08-4A8B-971F-2AB4C049405D

Type Material.
Holotype :
6, labeled as follows: “ KOREA : Gangwon Prov. , Gangreung-si , Okgyemyeon , Jusu-ri , Bondeung-bridge , N37°37’01.56" , E129°02’43.27"
5 m
,
27 V 2015
YH Kim, JH Song, DH Lee, JS Lee, ex near stream under stone; HOLOTYPE
Gnypeta koreana
Song and Ahn 2018”. Designated by J.-H. Song and K.-J. Ahn 2018 ( CNUIC )
.
Paratypes :
19 (total) – 1069 ♀ ( 262♀ on slides), same data as holotype ( CNUIC )
.

Description. Length 2.8–3.3 mm . Body ( Fig. 2 ) surface densely pubescent with microsculpture. Body black to dark brown, rarely brown; antennae and mouthparts reddish brown; legs reddish brown to yellowish brown. Head: Slightly transverse, about 1.1 times as wide as long, widest across eyes, narrower than pronotum; eyes slightly prominent, approximately 1.1 times as long as temples; gular sutures moderately separated, divergent basally. Antennae: Long and slender ( Fig. 3 ); antennomeres elongate, 1–3 distinctly elongate, 2 longer than 3, 4–8 elongate, 9–10 as long as wide, 11 longest, slightly shorter than preceding 2 antennomeres combined. Mouthparts: Labrum ( Fig. 4 ) transverse, slightly emarginate in anterior margin, with E -sensillum and 7 or 8 macrosetae on each side of midline; epipharynx with 2 lateral sensory rows on each side of midline; α- sensillum longest and setaceous, about 2.3 times as long as E -sensillum; β- and Ƴ- sensilla short. Mandibles ( Fig. 5 ) asymmetrical, long, curved and pointed apically, about 1.7 times as long as basal width; with several pores and 4 scrobal setae along outer surface; right mandible with small internal tooth, internal margin serrulate; prostheca developed. Galea and lacinia of maxilla ( Fig. 6 ) long and slender; lacinia with 7 spines in distal comb region, 2 longer isolated spines present; apical spines of distal comb region and isolated spines separated as long as distance from 1 st to last spines of distal comb region; maxillary palpus elongate and pubescent; palpomere 1 smallest, 2 about 2.9 times as long as wide, 3 longer than 2, about 2.6 times as long as wide, 4 digitiform, filamentous sensilla reaching to basal half. Labium ( Fig. 7 ) with ligula divided into 2 lobes in basal half; prementum with 2 medial setae very narrowly separated, longer than palpomere 1; 2 basal pores contiguous; few medial pseudopores, several lateral pseudopores, 1 setal pore and 2 or 3 real pores present on each side of midline; labial palpus elongate, with many setulae; palpomere 1 largest, longest and slightly dilated basally, about 2.4 times as long as wide, with 1 twin pore, 2 shortest, about 1.1 times as long as wide, with 1 median pore, 3 long, cylindrical, parallel-sided, about 3.2 times as long as wide, with 1 distal pore. Mentum ( Fig. 8 ) strongly transverse, trapezoidal, anterior margin slightly emarginate; with 4 macrosetae on each side of midline, v-seta reduced, w-seta slightly longer than u-seta. Thorax: Pronotum ( Fig. 2 ) slightly transverse, approximately 1.1–1.2 times as wide as long, widest at basal 2/3, pubescence directed antero-laterally, anteriorly in midline. Mesoventral process rounded at apex, slightly longer than metaventral process; metaventral process rounded at apex, slightly wider than mesoventral process, distinctly longer than isthmus. Elytra very convex, longer and wider than pronotum, elytron ( Fig. 2 ) approximately 1.5 times as long as wide, pubescence directed posteriorly and postero-laterally; postero-lateral margin slightly sinuate. Legs: Slender and long; length ratio of tarsomeres 26:22: 25:68 (protarsus); 27:36:27:30:55 (mesotarsus); 78: 46:42:42:64 (metatarsus); empodial seta absent. Abdomen: Parallel-sided; tergite VIII with 4 macrosetae on each side of midline ( Figs. 9, 11 ). Secondary sexual characteristics: Male tergite VIII ( Fig. 9 ) with posterior margin straight; male sternite VIII ( Fig. 10 ) with about 7 macrosetae on each side of midline, posterior margin almost rounded; female tergite VIII ( Fig. 11 ) with posterior margin almost straight; female sternite VIII ( Fig. 12 ) with 6 macrosetae on each side of midline, posterior margin slightly emarginate at apex. Aedeagus: Median lobe slightly concave medially, slightly bulbous at base in dorsal and ventral views ( Figs. 13–14 ), apical process elongate, triangularly produced in lateral and ventral views ( Figs. 14–15 ), rounded at apex in ventral aspect ( Fig. 14 ); internal sac with complex structures ( Figs. 13, 15 ). Apical lobe of paramerites with 3 setae; b-seta much longer than other setae, c- and d-setae close together. Spermatheca: S-shaped, bursa with broad, funnelshaped umbilicus; duct elongate and slender, recurved at apex ( Fig. 16 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 2. Habitus of
Gnypeta koreana
, holotype, male, 3.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Collection Data. The specimens of
G. koreana
were collected from under stones along edges of streams about 1.0 km from the East Sea (Sea of Japan ) coast of Gangreung-si, South Korea ( Fig. 1 ).

Remarks.
Gnypeta koreana
is morphologically similar to another Korean species,
G . opaca
, but the latter can be distinguished by antennomeres 4–9 subquadrate to slightly transverse and the different shape of spermatheca with a relatively large bursa.We could not examine any male specimens of
G . opaca
, because it was described based on a single female specimen from North Korea ( Bernhauer 1926 ).
